key_ideas: Positions of the planets in the Solar System
Relative positions of the Sun, the Earth and the Moon
investigations: Conduct a science mystery box experiment: objects are placed in sealed boxes and students make observations using their senses that may lead to inferences about the objects inside the boxes.
Use wire gauze to qualitatively determine the hottest part of the Bunsen burner flame.
Heat copper carbonate in a test tube to make qualitative observations and inferences.

Compare observations made using the senses to those made with technologies (compare visual, auditory or tactile observations of leaves, insects and flowers to observations made with digital photographs and recordings, bio viewers and microscope views, or electron micrograph images).
Use digital and analog thermometers to observe temperature changes during the day in shaded and unshaded areas.
Investigate insulation with water in aluminium cans by observing the effect of the colour of the insulating material on the temperature of can.
Investigate Dreaming stories of Aboriginal Peoples that are connected to the Universe.
Construct models to predict solar and lunar eclipses.
background_knowledge: The Earth is part of a system of planets orbiting around a star (the Sun).
Understanding of the Universe is developed by making observations and gathering data.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples use observations of the night sky to inform decisions about resources and significant Cultural night sky and weather patterns.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to make observations using their senses and a variety of technologies and tools appropriate for scientific observation. Students should also have the opportunity to develop and demonstrate their competency in safely following planned procedures to record both qualitative and quantitative observations.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
questioning and predicting using observations and measurements to answer questions posed
planning investigations by seeking permission to use specialised equipment
justifying how equipment choice affects the accuracy and precision of the measurements
analysing data and information using either observations collected over a period of time or provided data to identify trends, patterns and relationships, and draw conclusions.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.
A series of observations or fieldwork in the local area related to student-developed questions.
Extending the concept of tropism – including gravitropism, phototropism and thigmotropism – by conducting research into the effect of either gravity, light, or mechanical touch on plant growth.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students investigate how a recent advancement in science has increased our knowledge of the world and the Universe. This could be an opportunity for students to engage with scientific media and produce a written text or podcast to discuss the importance of collaboration and multiple perspectives in the advancement of science, for example:
explore how Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples' observations of the sky, the solar system and universe contributes to scientific knowledge.
scientific discoveries and advancements made possible by the collaboration of multiple agencies involved in running the International Space Station.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as pre-teaching vocabulary, scaffolds and provision to use home language or dialect to access scientific media and to produce persuasive texts.

investigations: Demonstrate the magnetic fields of bar magnets, horseshoe magnets and compasses, and their interactions using iron filings.
Investigate static electricity using charged rods (acrylic glass rod, silk, ebonite and wool) and pith balls.
Investigate static electricity by observing an electroscope or charging a balloon by rubbing it with cloth and trying to pick up small pieces of paper and/or feeling its effect on body hair.
Investigate friction using a spring balance to pull a mass across different types of surfaces, such as a carpet, tiles or a lab bench.
Compare calculated and measured mass using newton metres and digital scales.
Investigate the forces acting in Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ lives such as bow and arrow, tool sharpening or fire starting.
Construct and compare the strength of electromagnets by changing the core material or the number of turns in the wire coil and testing how many paperclips are picked up by the magnet.

Investigate the action of forces, such as: testing if the length of a lever arm affects the force required to lift an object; exploring how a pulley system can make lifting objects easier; or investigating how the angle of an inclined plane affects the force required to move an object uphill.
Investigate how simple machines can solve everyday issues such as using a spoon as a lever to open a jar lid.
background_knowledge: The movement of objects is dependent on forces.
How forces interact in a system to perform a function.
The effect of changing the amount of force on an object.
Magnets and objects that magnets will be attracted to.
The structure of the Earth.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to form questions about and make predictions regarding phenomena. Students should have the opportunity to follow a method and use scientific instruments to collect data which is then analysed in a variety of ways.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:

questioning and predicting by formulating questions to investigate and making predictions about a possible outcome, such as investigating the relationship between mass and the force required to move a block across a surface
collecting quantitative data using scientific equipment
collecting qualitative data and drawing conclusions
conducting investigations (including those modelled by the teacher), processing and analysing data and sharing scientific findings using a chosen communication method.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.

Investigating the effect of forces in toys or sport: students could investigate the nature of how forces act, how changing the nature of these forces (strength, direction) or the object (mass, friction) leads to different outcomes and how this relates to the desired outcome for the toy or sport.
Extending the concept of gears and how they work as simple machines: students could construct workable models of different-sized gears and investigate their use in real-world contexts.
Investigating complex machines: designing a complex machine out of as many simple machines as possible to solve a task.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students investigate forces and magnetism in familiar contexts. This may include areas such as transport (bikes), simple machines (levers), sports (football, cricket, softball) and toys (paper helicopters).
Students may present information through a written report, video, speech or demonstration on the effect of forces in everyday contexts. Students could investigate:
the nature of levers
pulley systems
designs to reduce the impact of friction
designs that rely on friction.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolds to produce written reports and provision to plan and discuss their speech using their home language or dialect.

investigations: Interpret dichotomous keys to classify a variety of organisms.
Survey of the local habitat using fieldwork, videos, images or field guides to identify native plant species and/or animals. Describe how organisms surveyed are adapted to their environment.
Make observations of cells and cell organelles using interactive online simulations, tactile models and microscopes.
Draw or collect images of single-celled organisms observed using a microscope.
Make a wet mount slide (eg onion cell, elodea, hay infusion, pond water) to observe and describe a variety of cells.
Compare similarities and differences between different types of cells, eg plant and animal cells, using images, tables, audio recordings or Venn diagrams.
Construct models to identify the process of photosynthesis and cellular respiration.
Model the process of diffusion and relate it to cellular respiration.
background_knowledge: features of living things
grouping living things according to their external features
the structural adaptations living things have that support their survival.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to observe and classify a variety of organisms using dichotomous keys and identify organisms using the Linnaean classification system. Students could develop their skills in observing, conducting investigations and communicating by using technologies to investigate cell specialisation and structures, and by making scientific diagrams and models.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
planning the investigation of species found in a local area
collecting data through a survey, recording the data in a table or spreadsheet, and analysing the data for patterns and trends.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.

Investigate a cellular process such as photosynthesis. Students pose questions, identify variables, and follow a planned procedure to make observations and draw evidence-based conclusions. Students document the process in the format of a procedural text.

Investigate the health of a local habitat such as a creek. Students identify organisms using keys, collect qualitative and quantitative observations about the biotic and abiotic features of the habitat, and identify adaptations that enable organisms to survive in this environment. Students could communicate with local groups such as Bushcare, NSW Waterwatch, local councils and Local Aboriginal Land Councils to evaluate their assessment of the health of the chosen habitat and discuss possible solutions and recommendations to maintain and/or improve the health and useability of the area.

Extend the concept of classification by investigating how the classification of a type of plant or animal has changed due to new discoveries or emerging technologies. Students could investigate how the light microscope led to the addition of other kingdoms such as Protista and Monera (bacteria).
Teaching advice (additional): Science 7–10 Depth study guide
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students research an organism to explain its classification and describe how classification encompasses all the characteristics of living things. Students could also research an Australian native animal (such as the platypus) and explain the features that lead scientists to classify it in a particular manner.
Kingdom: Animalia
Phylum: Chordata
Class: Mammalia
Order: Monotremata
Family: Ornithorhynchidae
Genus: Ornithorhynchus

Species: Ornithorhynchus anatinus Students could apply their understanding of the characteristics of living things to explain the classification of the platypus. Examples could include what they eat, how they grow and how they respond to changes in the environment.
This could be a good opportunity for students to produce a field guide, scientific news article or scientific poster that would be useful to display in a zoo.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolding, and provision to use their home language or dialect or a bilingual dictionary to research and produce a scientific news article.

key_ideas: Water can be found as a solid, liquid and gas
Classifying matter as pure substances (compounds) and impure substances (mixtures)
investigations: Measure the temperature as ice melts or water evaporates over a period of time.
Compare the density of water to other substances.
Investigate what substances are soluble in water.
Investigate the solubility of different solutes.
Investigate how temperature affects solubility.
Investigate the effect of salt on boiling point – 5% w/w, 10% w/w, 20% w/w, 30% w/w.
Investigate how to separate different types of mixtures.
Identify the cause-and-effect relationships involved in the cleaning of polluted water.
background_knowledge: Practice of science using Working scientifically processes, by conducting an investigation using scientific tools and tabulating and graphing data from an investigation.
All objects are made of materials which have certain properties.
The properties of materials affect how they are used.
Water can exist as a solid, liquid or gas.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to observe different chemistry phenomena by planning and conducting a number of practical investigations. Students should also be given the opportunity to use their knowledge in problem-solving by identifying different solutions and strategies.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:

planning an investigation to identify the independent, dependent and controlled variables when investigating the change in temperature of water as it is heated; the solubility of different substances; and the different methods used to separate mixtures
planning an investigation to understand the steps used to manage safety risks before, during and after an investigation
identify the methods and equipment needed when investigating the different methods used to separate mixtures
suggesting possible improvements to an investigation
conducting an investigation by selecting and/or assembling the correct equipment and following a planned procedure
processing data collected as part of investigations into density
analysing calculated density data and comparing it to SI units of measurement outlined in the  Science 7–10 Data Book
recording observations and measurements accurately during investigations.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.
Investigate the effect of temperature on how much solute can be dissolved in water to make supersaturated solutions.
Investigate how solutions are used in everyday products. This can be expanded to look at the growing market of cleaning solutions that are made into solids to decrease the use of plastic consumption.
Investigate how an understanding of separating of mixtures is used in the dairy industry to make butter, buttermilk or cottage cheese.
Research how blood can be separated to make plasma, red blood cell and platelet transfusions, and why these 3 methods have been developed.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students model how a body of water can be polluted and then plan and conduct a practical investigation to ‘clean’ the water they have polluted. For example, students could add small pieces of plastic to represent rubbish pollution, vinegar to represent acid rain, or dirt to represent land clearing and then plan an investigation to separate some of the pollutants. This could be an opportunity for students to produce a scientific report, newspaper article or presentation on how to remove or prevent pollutants in a body of water.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolds to produce a report or article, or the opportunity to plan and discuss their presentation using their home language or dialect.

This is a good opportunity for the students to learn how to conduct a second-hand research activity after researching their local water catchment area and identifying where that water comes from. Additionally, students could research what factors could contribute to a body of water becoming polluted and how that could be prevented.

key_ideas: Movement of nutrients and waste in plants and animals
Disorders and their impact on a system
Ecosystems are determined by their abiotic and biotic factors
Matter and energy cycles in a system
investigations: Dissect plants to observe roots, flowers, stems and leaves.
Observe water movement in xylem and transpiration using a celery experiment.
Observe onion cells using microscopes with iodine or the tactile model.
Use stereo microscopes (×40) or diagrams for leaf, flower, root and stem examination.
Model local food webs and ecosystem matter/energy flows.

Research and compare different living systems and then predict what could happen if a part of that system is missing or damaged, eg the effect on an individual without an organ such as a kidney or a spleen, or the effect on a plant without its leaves, roots or flowers.

Investigate the influence of biotic and abiotic factors on organisms, such as how food availability (eucalyptus leaves) and climate (extreme temperature) interact to affect the distribution and health of koala populations in different parts of Australia.
background_knowledge: Living things change over time.
Living things require energy.
The balance of nutrients and organisms in an environment.
How physical conditions affect the survival of living things.
The conditions needed for a particular plant or animal to grow and survive.
How changing physical conditions in an environment affect the growth and survival of living things.
How the structural and behavioural features of living things support their survival.
Multicellular organisms are made up of a variety of specialised cells and tissues that support their needs.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to develop their skills in researching information to make valid predictions, process data and information, and use appropriate models to communicates ideas.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
investigating human systems (eg digestive, circulatory, respiratory or excretory) using scientific knowledge of human systems to question and predict the effects of disorders to part of a system
extracting information from texts, diagrams or multimedia to identify and label images of cells
using models (eg food webs, pyramids, or carbon/oxygen/nitrogen/water cycles) to simplify and represent complex phenomena
presenting findings with relevant scientific terms and diagrams for a specific purpose and audience.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.
Comparing 2 different ecosystems by examining the abiotic and biotic features in each.
Comparing structural features of different plants in an ecosystem.
Investigating the history of organ transplants or possible future advances in this area.
Extending understanding of the impact of disease on a human body system, eg the impact of coeliac disease on the digestive system.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students are required to investigate factors that have led to a species becoming endangered or extinct and explain why Australia has some of the world’s highest extinction rates. Each group of students could research one extinct or endangered animal, such as the Tasmanian tiger or the lesser bilby, and then develop a presentation such as a poster, video or report describing the factors that led to the endangerment or extinction of their chosen animal.

Students could then go on a mock ‘field trip’ through the class, moving between presentations to learn the reasons for each animal’s endangerment or extinction. Once all data has been collected, the class could work together to come up with explanations for Australia’s high extinction rates. Possible explanations might include geographical isolation or habitat destruction.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolds and provision to use their home language or dialect and a bilingual dictionary to research, plan and produce a presentation.

key_ideas: Subatomic particles – protons, neutrons and electrons
Physical properties of metals, metalloids and non-metals
Uses of elements, compounds and alloys
investigations: Investigate the physical properties of metals, non-metals and metalloids such as their melting and boiling point, thermal and electrical conductivity, ductility or malleability.
Investigate the uses of common elements, compounds and alloys such as copper for electrical wiring, sodium bicarbonate used in baking, or steel used in building.
Investigate tests used to identify metals and non-metals such as tests for gases – oxygen, hydrogen and carbon dioxide or flame tests for some metal ions.
Investigate how models of atomic structure have changed over time including the contributions of Dalton, Rutherford, Bohr, Thompson and Chadwick.
Investigate the history of the periodic table to design a timeline for the classroom.
background_knowledge: All objects are made of materials which have certain properties.
The properties of materials affect their use.
The purpose of science is to build knowledge and understanding of the world.
Advancements in science are often the result of collaboration.
Matter can display different properties as a solid, liquid or gas.
Mixtures and pure substances have different properties.
Metals are used in the production of tools.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
conducting an investigation to identify the physical properties of metals, non-metals and metalloids
modelling atomic structure by proton, neutron and electron numbers of the first 18 elements
processing and analysing data and information from texts, diagrams, flow charts and multimedia to identify the historical changes in the atomic structure

assessing the reliability of gathered data and information when researching, eg how technologies have helped shape our understanding of the model of the atom, or the elemental composition of the Earth compared to another planet
making predictions using identified patterns and relationships in the periodic table
proposing inferences based on presented data and information when investigating tests to identify metal and non-metal elements.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.
Research the ‘ancient’ elements (gold, silver, iron, lead, tin, sulfur) and explain why their properties suited their function.
Design a periodic table of unknown elements based on their physical properties and abilities to react with hydrochloric acid.
Research how new technologies have filled in some of the unstable elements in periods 6 and 7 of the periodic table.
Investigate the relationship between element properties, technology, discovery and use.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students are required to investigate how the properties and availability of materials influence their uses. This would be a good opportunity for students to research different metals, alloys and compounds to develop a better understanding of abundance and how these materials are found in nature. Students could investigate:
why certain elements are found mainly as compounds in nature, such as sodium, which is found mainly as sodium chloride
why gold and silver are used for jewellery
why steel and bronze became popular alloys
why it took so long to discover some elements
how the abundance of high-grade iron ore in Australia has led to a thriving steel industry.
This could be an opportunity for students to produce a persuasive text on why an element or compound’s use has changed due to evolving technology or trends.
Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as explicit teaching of the language of persuasion and the use of scaffolds to produce persuasive text.

investigations: Undertake qualitative observations of convection currents in liquids, eg boiling rice, lava lamps.
Carry out quantitative observations of radiant energy heating materials, eg radiation cans, different coloured fabrics in the Sun.

Plan a valid investigation to collect qualitative and quantitative observations of energy transformations, eg bouncing a ball (gravitational, kinetic and elastic), observing elastic potential energy stored in a spring or elastic band, using solar panels to convert light energy into electrical energy.
Investigate the law of conservation of energy, eg energy transformations in a pendulum.

Make qualitative observations to compare the difference between physical and chemical changes, eg breaking a paddle pop stick into pieces versus burning it, malleability of magnesium ribbon versus burning magnesium.
Observe the conduction of heat through different materials, eg metals and insulators.
Investigate energy changes in chemical reactions using data loggers or thermometers to measure temperature changes, eg vinegar and bicarbonate of soda, handwarmers.
Use mineral kits to compare the observable properties of different types of minerals and rocks.
Use images and multimodal simulations to observe large-scale geological changes.
Investigate observations made that support the theory of plate tectonics.
background_knowledge: Types of energy.
The effect of geological change on the Earth’s surface.
How matter and energy are cycled through a system.
Cellular processes.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.
In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to:
follow planned procedures and use scientific tools and instruments to make observations of energy transfers and transformations
conduct investigations to identify indicators that a chemical change has occurred
observe energy changes in a chemical reaction.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
questioning and predicting using models and simulations to investigate energy transformations, including the transformation of radiant energy into electrical energy
questioning and predicting using a variety of models to investigate change, including the rock cycle to model geological processes, formation of fossils and the law of superposition.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.

Investigate the chemical reaction between yeast and sugar (fermentation) to produce carbon dioxide. Observe the indicators of a chemical change (gas), and confirm the products produced. Investigate variables affecting fermentation such as temperature and type of sugar used and measure the amount of gas produced.
Investigate the location of plate boundaries and volcanic activity.
Extend knowledge of chemical change to identify applications in daily living, eg exploring traditional bush foods and medicines (using soft bracken fern to treat insect bites).
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students are required to observe or design a chain reaction machine. Students could design and construct a Rube Goldberg machine to represent energy stores and transfers within a complex system. Students could stack several dominoes vertically as a potential energy store.

Process: Attach a string to the top domino. At the top, place a small toy car on a small, inclined ramp. When the dominoes fall, they release potential energy, which is transferred to the toy car. The toy car accelerates down the ramp, converting the potential energy into kinetic energy. At the bottom of the ramp, the toy car collides with a wooden block, transferring its kinetic energy to the block.
Students could document the energy transfers as a factual description or descriptive report.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolds and explicit teaching of the language of description to produce a description or descriptive report.

key_ideas: Scientific models, including different types and their predictive power
Accuracy and reliability of primary data
Using statistics including mean and range to analyse data
investigations: Conducting a practical investigation to collect a dataset, eg a survey of food preferences of a class or year group, fieldwork to observe and track changes in biotic and abiotic features such as vegetation type and distribution, temperature, moisture, and light intensity.
Engaging with relevant local groups such as the local council, Bushcare, Aboriginal Land Councils or national parks to identify issues such as pests and weeds, collect data, and propose solutions.

Analysing computer-generated models, eg weather modelling, predicting the path of asteroids, biodiversity and population models, including the use of these models to make predictions, and identifying the data that scientists used to generate these models.
background_knowledge: Testable questions.
Predicting based on observation or evidence.
Processing numerical data.
Variables in scientific investigations.
Calculating mean and range.
Describing trends, patterns and relationships in data.
Scientific models and theories.
skills: Working scientifically processes which are most relevant for the intended learning have been identified for each focus area.

In this focus area, students should be given the opportunity to explore how data can be analysed using simple descriptive statistics, including mean and range, and apply this to evaluate the accuracy and reliability of data collected. Analysed data can be used to identify possible strategies to solve identified problems.
Additional examples of how to embed Working scientifically processes in this focus area include:
identifying investigable questions and making predictions using a dataset or through primary investigation.
depth_studies: Depth studies are an opportunity for students to pursue an area of strength or interest. The following are suggestions for depth studies.

Develop questions that can be investigated either using a provided dataset or through first-hand investigation. For example, students could investigate the effect of soil salinity on germination or growth rates, the effectiveness of energy-efficient house designs, how ocean acidification affects shellfish or corals, whether warmer sea temperatures cause stronger cyclones.
Plan and conduct an investigation to identify and collect relevant data, process and analyse the data and draw evidence-based conclusions that address their identified question.
Use a dataset, investigate different ways that data can be presented, and assess how trends, patterns and relationships can be effectively communicated to a specific audience.
Investigate the achievements of Aboriginal scientists.

Extend understanding of models by investigating 2 competing theories that explain the origin of the universe, eg the Big Bang model and steady-state theory. Compare observations and evidence that support each model and explain why the model is accepted or rejected.
Teaching advice (additional): Stage 4 and Stage 5 – Developing talent in Science
in_context: Students are required to create a model that can be used to explain an observable phenomenon, such as:
a simple machine to show how levers can be used as a force multiplier, eg trebuchet, pulleys and gears
a model of an organ or organ system to demonstrate its function
a model of the particles to demonstrate expansion and contraction in a familiar material such as an elastic hair band or a car tyre
a model of specific phenomena in our solar system, eg eclipses, predicted path of comets and asteroids, sunspots.

This could be an opportunity for students to produce an explanation through a written report, video or speech to identify strong cause-and-effect links. This is also an opportunity for students to develop their skills in evaluating an explanation and model against a provided rubric.

Students learning English as an additional language or dialect (EAL/D) may require support such as scaffolds and explicit teaching of language features such as cause-and-effect and prediction to produce an explanation.
